title: Consensus Decision Paralysis
context: Consensus-driven decision-making is the default in many organizations, especially in tech. The logic is appealing: get everyone's input, ensure buy-in, make better decisions through diverse perspectives. In practice, consensus requirements create decision paralysis. Every stakeholder has veto power. Meetings multiply as groups try to align. Decisions get watered down to the lowest common denominator that nobody objects to but nobody is excited about. The most important decisions — the ones that require bold tradeoffs — are exactly the ones consensus can't produce, because bold tradeoffs create losers, and consensus requires that nobody loses. Organizations that optimize for consensus optimize for mediocrity and speed-to-nothing.
hypothesis: Consensus-based decisions ensure buy-in and produce better outcomes.

effects.label: Decision speed collapses
effects.impact: Consensus decisions take 3-5x longer than single-owner decisions

children.label: Every stakeholder must be consulted, scheduled, and aligned
One dissenter can block or delay indefinitely
Decisions that should take days take weeks or months

effects.label: Decisions converge to lowest common denominator
effects.impact: Bold options eliminated because someone objects

children.label: Compromise produces mediocre outcomes that satisfy nobody fully
Strategic differentiation impossible — consensus favors safe, incremental choices

effects.label: Accountability diffuses — nobody owns the outcome
effects.impact: 'We all decided' means nobody is responsible when it fails

children.label: Post-mortems can't identify decision owner because there isn't one
Course correction delayed because changing a consensus decision requires new consensus
Learned helplessness — individuals stop proposing bold ideas because consensus will kill them

effects.label: Meeting culture metastasizes to support consensus process
effects.impact: 30-50% of work time spent in alignment meetings

children.label: Pre-meetings to align before the meeting, post-meetings to confirm alignment
Decision fatigue from constant consensus-seeking reduces quality of all decisions

dontIf: The decision is time-sensitive and delay costs more than imperfect alignment
You're using consensus as a way to avoid accountability for difficult choices
ifYouMust: Set explicit time limits on consensus-seeking — if no consensus in 48 hours, designated owner decides
Distinguish between 'input' and 'approval' — gather input from many, but limit approval to 2-3 people
Use disagree-and-commit — once decided, everyone executes regardless of initial position
Reserve consensus for truly irreversible decisions — use single-owner for everything else

alternatives.name: RACI framework
alternatives.note: One person Responsible, one Accountable, others Consulted or Informed — clear ownership

alternatives.name: Advice process
alternatives.note: Decision owner must seek advice from affected parties but makes the final call alone

alternatives.name: Disagree and commit
alternatives.note: Amazon's model — debate vigorously, then commit fully to the decision regardless of initial position

sources.title: Harvard Business Review: The Consensus Trap

sources.title: Amazon Leadership Principles: Disagree and Commit

sources.title: McKinsey: Decision Making in Organizations

falsifiability: Consensus-driven organizations consistently make faster decisions than single-owner organizations
Consensus decisions produce measurably better outcomes than decisions made by empowered individuals with input
Employee satisfaction with decision-making increases as consensus requirements expand
